repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem

1. Highlights from injections might get obscured by parent highlights with the same priority. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31777
2. Ephemeral and regular extmarks with the same priorities might change the order they appear depending on how they are redrawn. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30869#issuecomment-2430570060

### Solution

Add `subpriority` field to `nvim_buf_set_extmarks()` `opts` that allows further control over the order of highlights. 

1 is fixed by drawing each highlight state with a higher subpriority than the previous. Regular `priority` values still work as expected. Subpriority only breaks the ties in favor of child injections.
2 is fixed by making regular extmarks use subpriority of 0 when drawn. The highlighter starts subpriorities from 1, so ephemeral extmarks are always drawn on top of regular extmarks with the same priority. 

Should `subpriority` be documented?

fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31777

comment_data.body: Comparison changed from `<` to `<=`. Should work identically, since `ordering` (now a part of priority) is unique.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -203,11 +203,11 @@ function TSHighlighter:prepare_highlight_states(srow, erow)
   end)
 end
 
----@param fn fun(state: vim.treesitter.highlighter.State)
+---@param fn fun(state: vim.treesitter.highlighter.State, index: number)

comment_data.body: I think we should try to implement this without subpriority. We can just shift all the current base priorities by some magnitude to give us enough space for priorities in between.

I don't know what priorities other than 100 should do. I know priority 99 was used at least once to make a highlight get obscured by parent highlight: https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/pull/5649.

There's also a question about whether highlights > 100 should appear above all other highlights from other trees, or only child highlights, or only this tree's highlights.

comment_regular_data.body:
We wanted to introduce subpriorities then because the highlighter was changed to use `iter_matches` from `iter_captures` in order to maintain highlight behaviour.

In the end I think I (or someone) figured out how to implement what we wanted with `iter_captures` so we reverted the subpriorities change since it was no longer needed.
Yes, but there was some (critical) discussion around subpriorities, and I think those points apply here as well and should be considered.

I don't think anyone really wanted it, but it was seen as a simple means to an ends, but @bfredl did somewhat object that it wasn't necessary, and my opinion has tipped over time into that direction. Priority is already a 64bit integer, which should allow plenty of room for everything we need.

> Priority is already a 64bit integer, which should allow plenty of room for everything we need.

Priority is limited to 65'535 at least in the extmarks.
Ok my mistake. That's still a large number though.

> 2 is fixed by making regular extmarks use subpriority of 0 when drawn. The highlighter starts subpriorities from 1, so ephemeral extmarks are always drawn on top of regular extmarks with the same priority.

Does this suggest that we need a `kind:string` field on extmarks? It looks like subpriorities are used to encode semantics with numbers instead of an explicit "kind". (Correct me if wrong :)

Subpriorities only resolve 1 level of conflicts, right?

> Does this suggest that we need a `kind:string` field on extmarks? It looks like subpriorities are used to encode semantics with numbers instead of an explicit "kind". (Correct me if wrong :)
> 
> Subpriorities only resolve 1 level of conflicts, right?

Not sure what that means.

Usually, regular extmarks are added at the last possible moment, and thus their highlight is applied on top of other decorations with the same priority.

But that is not the case for when the process is first started. The first extmark (and possibly others) are added before everything else, and get obscured by other declarations with the same priority.

The same happens with multiline regular extmarks. When they are first added, they appear above. But on the next line, new decorations (with the same priority) are added and now the extmark is behind them.

> regular extmarks are added at the last possible moment

So does it make sense to annotate non-regular extmarks with a field that indicates this with a name (different names for different kinds of "non-regular" extmarks), instead of a secondary (numeric) priority?
How would we use that to control ordering/priority of extmarks? How are the names compared?
Would need to be enum-like so the names have ordering. However, reviewing how `treesitter/highlighter.lua` uses `subpriority`, I see now that names aren't a good fit.

Can #31777 be solved without messing with priorities? I wonder if this could be done completely within the highlighter, seeing as it is not the case that all injections render weirdly, just combined ones

Not sure if it matters, but there are situations where the same behavior will happen for regular injections: 

<details>

```lua
for name, url in pairs {
  nvim_treesitter = 'https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter.git',
  'https://github.com/rose-pine/neovim.git'
} do
  local install_path = vim.fn.fnamemodify('nvim_issue/' .. name, ':p')
  if vim.fn.isdirectory(install_path) == 0 then
    vim.fn.system { 'git', 'clone', '--depth=1', url, install_path }
  end
  vim.opt.runtimepath:append(install_path)
end

require'nvim-treesitter.configs'.setup {
  sync_install = true,
  ensure_installed = { "javascript", "styled" },
  highlight = { enable = true },
}

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, {
  'css`',
  '.test {',
  '    prop: "5',
  '    ${a} ${b}  3";',
  '}',
  '`',
})

vim.treesitter.start(0, 'javascript')

vim.treesitter.query.set(
  'javascript',
  'highlights',
  [[(string_fragment) @fragment]]
)

vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, "@fragment.javascript", { bg = 'green', italic = true })
vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, "@string.styled", { bg = 'red' })
```

</details>
